[Assess] Bracero Farmworker Case Study

📍 Yakima Valley, WA

September 19, 2025

Centering Activity

  • Reena :-)

Exit Ticket Results

Setting the Stage

  • This week’s focus is on data tidying and transformation
  • Using metadata from 90 interviews in the Bracero Archive that I scraped
  • Important to note that each row represents a person, a life, and a family impacted by the Bracero Program

Learning Outcomes

  • Understand data structure
  • Transform and tidy data for necessary questions
  • Explore and summarize patterns
  • Connect your findings to theoretical understandings of procedural justice

Let’s get Started

  • Find your pair
  • Open Posit

First Steps

  • Import Data
  • Load packages
    • You may need to install readxl using install.packages("package name").
library(readxl) # for loading data
library(tidyverse) # for tidying
# | eval: true
# | echo: false
bracero <- read_excel("~/Google Drive/My Drive/Teaching/ES-202/Case Study Code/data/week_03/bracero_pull.xlsx")

Load Data

bracero <- read_excel("data/bracero_pull.xlsx")

Our data

  • 90 rows (interviews)
  • 6 variables (all chr type)
    • title = Person interviewed
    • subject = topic of interview
    • description = summary of interview
    • date = date of interview
    • identifier = link to original interview file
    • language = language interview was conducted in
glimpse(bracero)
Rows: 90
Columns: 6
$ title       <chr> "Richard Hancock", "Pedro Cantor", "Asterio López León", "…
$ subject     <chr> "Doña Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac…
$ description <chr> "Biographical Synopsis of Interviewee:  Richard Hancock wa…
$ date        <chr> "2003-04-21", "2005-07-27", "2006-05-22", "2005-09-01", "2…
$ identifier  <chr> "https://braceroarchive.org/items/show/82;https://braceroa…
$ language    <chr> "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s…

Variable Types

We will work primarily with five types of variables in this course:

  • chr is character
  • dbl is double (number)
  • int is an integer
  • date is date
  • fct is factor

Thoughts on what variables we may want to change the data types of?

Rows: 90
Columns: 6

$ subject     <chr> "Doña Ana County Farm Bureau", "Bracero", "Bracero", "Brac…

$ language    <chr> "eng", "spa", "spa", "spa", "eng", "spa", "spa", "eng", "s…

Transforming Data (Columns)

  • Four functions can change the columns of your data without affecting your rows
    • mutate(): creates new columns based on existing ones
    • select(): chooses what columns you want in your dataframe
    • rename(): changes the names of current columns
    • relocate(): changes the position of those columns

mutate() function

  • mutate() creates new columns based on existing ones
  • We use the mutate() function to create a new column year, using the year() function to change the original date column to include only the year, formatted as a date.
bracero <- bracero |>
  mutate(year = year(date))

mutate() function (cont.)

  • We can also pair it with additional functions, such as ifelse statements.
    • %in%c() allows you to list multiple matches in the subject column.

bracero |> 
 mutate(subject_binary = ifelse(subject %in%c("bracero", "Bracero"), "Bracero", "Non-bracero"))
# A tibble: 90 × 8
   title      subject description date  identifier language  year subject_binary
   <chr>      <chr>   <chr>       <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <dbl> <chr>         
 1 Richard H… Doña A… "Biographi… 2003… https://b… eng       2003 Non-bracero   
 2 Pedro Can… Bracero "Biographi… 2005… https://b… spa       2005 Bracero       
 3 Asterio L… Bracero "Biographi… 2006… https://b… spa       2006 Bracero       
 4 Vincente … Bracero "Biographi… 2005… https://b… spa       2005 Bracero       
 5 Inez Rios  Intera… "Biographi… 2003… https://b… eng       2003 Non-bracero   
 6 Manuel En… Bureau… "Biographi… 2003… https://b… spa       2003 Non-bracero   
 7 Alberto M… Bracero "Biographi… 2005… https://b… spa       2005 Bracero       
 8 Ernesto E… Son of… "Biographi… 2005… https://b… eng       2005 Non-bracero   
 9 Jesús Ort… Bracero "Biographi… 2005… https://b… spa       2005 Bracero       
10 José G. C… Son of… "Biographi… 2005… https://b… spa       2005 Non-bracero   
# ℹ 80 more rows

select() function

  • select() can be used to select or deselect columns.
  • Perhaps we’d like to remove the original date column from our dataframe.
# select column you don't want
bracero |>
 select(-date)

# select columns you do want
bracero |>
 select(title, subject, description, date, identifier, language, year)

# select columns in a row, except the column you don't want
bracero |>
  select(title:description, identifier:year)

rename() function

  • rename() changes the names of current columns
    • let’s rename title to something more descriptive like interviewee.
bracero |>
  rename("interviewee" = "title")
# A tibble: 90 × 7
   interviewee              subject  description date  identifier language  year
   <chr>                    <chr>    <chr>       <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <dbl>
 1 Richard Hancock          Doña An… "Biographi… 2003… https://b… eng       2003
 2 Pedro Cantor             Bracero  "Biographi… 2005… https://b… spa       2005
 3 Asterio López León       Bracero  "Biographi… 2006… https://b… spa       2006
 4 Vincente Delgado         Bracero  "Biographi… 2005… https://b… spa       2005
 5 Inez Rios                Interac… "Biographi… 2003… https://b… eng       2003
 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau … "Biographi… 2003… https://b… spa       2003

 8 Ernesto Espino           Son of … "Biographi… 2005… https://b… eng       2005

10 José G. Corral           Son of … "Biographi… 2005… https://b… spa       2005
# ℹ 80 more rows

relocate() function

  • relocate() changes the position of columns
  • relocate() automatically puts the column at the front, so you have to specify the column’s location, and .after or .before.
bracero |> 
 relocate(identifier, .after = language)
# A tibble: 90 × 7
   title                    subject  description date  language identifier  year
   <chr>                    <chr>    <chr>       <chr> <chr>    <chr>      <dbl>
 1 Richard Hancock          Doña An… "Biographi… 2003… eng      https://b…  2003
 2 Pedro Cantor             Bracero  "Biographi… 2005… spa      https://b…  2005
 3 Asterio López León       Bracero  "Biographi… 2006… spa      https://b…  2006
 4 Vincente Delgado         Bracero  "Biographi… 2005… spa      https://b…  2005
 5 Inez Rios                Interac… "Biographi… 2003… eng      https://b…  2003
 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau … "Biographi… 2003… spa      https://b…  2003
 7 Alberto Montes González  Bracero  "Biographi… 2005… spa      https://b…  2005
 8 Ernesto Espino           Son of … "Biographi… 2005… eng      https://b…  2005
 9 Jesús Ortíz Torres       Bracero  "Biographi… 2005… spa      https://b…  2005
10 José G. Corral           Son of … "Biographi… 2005… spa      https://b…  2005
# ℹ 80 more rows

Put it together

  • We can put all of these data transformation actions together using the |> function
    • line 1: creates new dataframe called bracero_clean
    • line 2: creates formatted year column called year from the original date column.
    • line 3: selects for all columns except for the old date column
    • line 4: renames the title column to interviewee
    • line 5: moves the indentifier column to after the year column.
bracero_clean <- bracero |>
  mutate(year = year(date)) |> 
  select(-date) |> 
  rename("interviewee" = "title") |> 
  relocate(identifier, .after = year)

Exercise One

  • Starting with the bracero dataframe, code the following three actions using into a new dataframe called bracero_ex1
    • mutate the date column into a new column, called year using the year() function.
    • select the title, year, and description columns.
    • relocate the year column to be the first in the dataframe.

Transforming Data (Rows)

  • Moving on to rows!
    • filter() is a function that allows you to keep rows of interest (but won’t change the order of your rows)
    • arrange() changes the order of your rows (but won’t filter for anything)

filter() function

  • Use the filter() function to select rows that correspond to values of interest.
  • use == to filter the language column for rows with a direct match (in this case spa)
bracero_clean |>
  filter(language == "spa")
# A tibble: 75 × 6
   interviewee              subject        description language  year identifier
   <chr>                    <chr>          <chr>       <chr>    <dbl> <chr>     
 1 Pedro Cantor             Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
 2 Asterio López León       Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2006 https://b…
 3 Vincente Delgado         Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
 4 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp… "Biographi… spa       2003 https://b…
 5 Alberto Montes González  Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
 6 Jesús Ortíz Torres       Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
 7 José G. Corral           Son of a brac… "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
 8 Eduardo De Santiago      Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2003 https://b…
 9 Salvador Torres Beltrán  Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2006 https://b…
10 Luis Zamudio Villagomez  Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
# ℹ 65 more rows

filter() operations

  • > greater than

  • >= greater than or equal to

  • < less than

  • <= less than or equal to

  • == equal to

  • != does not equal

  • Can use & to combine conditions (and)

  • | to select multiple conditions (or)

  • Perhaps we’re interested in interviews that took place after 2004 AND are in English:

bracero_clean |>
  filter(year >= 2004 & language == "eng")

filter() and str_detect()

  • We can also combine filter with the str_detect() function, to look for character matches in a column (in this case the interviewee column, with any matches including Alberto .
bracero_clean |> 
  filter(str_detect(interviewee, "Alberto"))
# A tibble: 3 × 6
  interviewee              subject description         language  year identifier
  <chr>                    <chr>   <chr>               <chr>    <dbl> <chr>     
1 Alberto Montes González  Bracero "Biographical Syno… spa       2005 https://b…
2 Alberto Magallón Jiménez Bracero "Biographical Syno… spa       2005 https://b…
3 Alberto Mendoza Torres   bracero "Biographical Syno… spa       2003 https://b…

arrange()

  • arrange() sorts your rows based on the values in the columns.
  • If you sort more than one row, it will sort the first variable, and the others will be used to “break ties”
  • including desc() will sort your column values big to small.
bracero_clean |> 
  arrange(desc(year, interviewee))

Exercise Two

  1. Filter the bracero_ex_1 dataframe for any interviews that took place before 2005 (using the year column) with an interviewee whose name includes “Guadalupe”.

  2. Arrange the bracero_ex1 data frame in descending order by year. What was the year, how many interviews took place in that year, and who is listed first?

  3. Filter the bracero_clean dataframe for any description columns that mention “California”. How many interviewees are there?

Grouping Data

group_by() function

  • group_by() function is really helpful for sorting your data into groups for analysis.
  • group_by() function does not change your data, but will change subsequent operations if you use them in tandem with a group_by()
  • You can also group by multiple columns. In this case, I’ve grouped by both year and language
 bracero_clean |>
  group_by(year, language)
# A tibble: 90 × 6
# Groups:   year, language [6]
   interviewee              subject        description language  year identifier
   <chr>                    <chr>          <chr>       <chr>    <dbl> <chr>     
 1 Richard Hancock          Doña Ana Coun… "Biographi… eng       2003 https://b…
 2 Pedro Cantor             Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
 3 Asterio López León       Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2006 https://b…
 4 Vincente Delgado         Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
 5 Inez Rios                Interaction w… "Biographi… eng       2003 https://b…
 6 Manuel Enriquez Savignac Bureau of Emp… "Biographi… spa       2003 https://b…
 7 Alberto Montes González  Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
 8 Ernesto Espino           Son of bracero "Biographi… eng       2005 https://b…
 9 Jesús Ortíz Torres       Bracero        "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
10 José G. Corral           Son of a brac… "Biographi… spa       2005 https://b…
# ℹ 80 more rows

summarize()

  • summarize() is often used in tandem with the group_by() function to calculate summary statistic(s) for a group.
  • In this case we are grouping the bracero_clean dataframe by the values in the language column, and summarizing the number of interviews using the n() function in a new column called n_interviews.
bracero_clean |>
 group_by(language) |>
 summarize(n_interviews = n())
# A tibble: 2 × 2
  language n_interviews
  <chr>           <int>
1 eng                15
2 spa                75

Other summarize functions

  • You can summarize values across groups using other functions, such as:
    • median() = median
    • mean() = average
    • sum() = sum
bracero_clean |>
 group_by(language) |>
 summarize(avg_date = mean(year))
# A tibble: 2 × 2
  language avg_date
  <chr>       <dbl>
1 eng         2004.
2 spa         2004.

slice

  • slice_ functions help select a subset of rows
  • slice_head(n = 5) will take the first five rows of the data
  • slice_tail(n = 5) will take the last five rows of the data
  • slice_min(x, n = 5) will take the five rows of data with the lowest values for column x.
  • slice_max(x, n = 5) will take the five rows of data with the highest values for column x.
  • slice_sample(n = 5) will select 5 random rows of data.
bracero_clean |>
  slice_min(year, n = 3)
# A tibble: 8 × 6
  interviewee             subject description          language  year identifier
  <chr>                   <chr>   <chr>                <chr>    <dbl> <chr>     
1 Heriberto Cortéz Cortéz Bracero "Biographical Synop… spa       2002 https://b…
2 Gregorio Corrales Rojas Bracero "Biographical Synop… spa       2002 https://b…
3 Héctor Solís Fuentes    Bracero "Biographical Synop… spa       2002 https://b…
4 Homero López Ortiz      Bracero "Biographical Synop… spa       2002 https://b…
5 Patricio Corrales Rojas Bracero "Biographical Synop… spa       2002 https://b…
6 Liborio Santiago Pérez  Bracero "Biographical Synop… spa       2002 https://b…
7 Herminio Quezada Durán  Bracero "Biographical Synop… spa       2002 https://b…
8 Rodolfo Cruz Figueroa   Bracero "Biographical Synop… spa       2002 https://b…
